{{Infobox font | name = {{lang|de|Fälschungserschwerende Schrift}} | image = FONT-FE-SCHRIFT.png | style = [[Sans-serif]] | creationdate = 1978–1980 | creator = [[Karlgeorg Hoefer]] | foundry = {{lang|de|Bundesanstalt für Straßenwesen}} | sample = [[File:FE-Schrift.svg|300px|center]] | aka = FE-Schrift
Schrift für Kfz-Kennzeichen |}} [[File:Fe-Schrift-Manipulation.png|thumb|A demonstration of attempted alteration of characters set in the FE-Schrift typeface. The series "PBF" (top row) is modified to read "R3E" (middle row, in red). The correct appearance of the series "R3E" is shown in the bottom row.]] The '''{{lang|de|FE-Schrift}}'''{{lang|de|Schrift für Kfz-Kennzeichen. Bundesanstalt für Straßenwesen, Bergisch Gladbach, Germany.}} or '''{{lang|de|Fälschungserschwerende Schrift}}''' ('''forgery-impeding typeface''') is a [[typeface]] introduced for use on [[license plate]]s. Its monospaced letters and numbers are slightly disproportionate to prevent easy modification and to improve machine readability. It has been developed in Germany where it has been mandatory since November 2000.[http://www.stvzo.de/stvzo/fzv/anlage_4.htm {{lang|de|StVO, FZV – Anlage 4}}] The abbreviation "FE" is derived from the compound German adjective "{{lang|de|'''f'''älschungs'''e'''rschwerend}}" combining the noun "{{lang|de|Fälschung}}" (falsification) and the verb "{{lang|de|erschweren}}" (to hinder). "{{lang|de|Schrift}}" means [[font]] in German. Other countries have later introduced the same or a derived typeface for license plates taking advantage of the proven design for the FE-Schrift. == Development == The motivation for the creation of the typeface was spun in the late 1970s in the light of [[Red Army Faction]] [[terrorism]] when it was discovered that with the then-standard font for vehicle registration plates—the [[DIN 1451]] font—it was particularly easy to modify letters by applying a small amount of black paint or tape. For example, it was easy to change a "P" to an "R" or "B", a "3" to an "8", or an "L" or "F" to an "E". Modifications to FE-font plates are somewhat more difficult, as they also require the use of white paint, which is easily distinguished at a distance from the [[retroreflective]] white background of the plate, in particular at night. The original design for the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} typeface was created by [[Karlgeorg Hoefer]] who was working for the {{lang|de|Bundesanstalt für Straßenwesen}} (Federal Highway Research Institute of Germany) at the time. The typeface was slightly modified according to the results of tests that lasted from 1978 to 1980 at the University of Giessen (Department of Physiology and Cybernetic Psychology).http://www.fsd.it/usefuldesign/german_plates_font.htm Whilst the DIN typeface was using a [[proportional font]], the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} is a [[monospaced font]] (with different spacing for letters and numbers) for improved machine readability. Faked {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} letters (e.g., "P" to "R") appear conspicuously disproportionate. Another motivation for the new typeface came from a spike in the theft rate of license plates in the early 1970s. And despite the requirement to hinder falsification, the scope document did list that point only in the second place. The first priority was a requirement for readability by humans and machines as the decade was the same that saw the development of other typefaces for [[optical character recognition]], namely [[OCR-A]] and [[OCR-B]]. The RAF terrorism however allowed to fund a project over a couple of years — running from the functional scope document being created in 1977 to the final decision of 1982 to not introduce the design on license plates. It ended up in the drawer.{{cite web |url=https://de.scribd.com/document/190327472/Falschungserschwerende-Schrift |title=Fälschungserschwerende Schrift |work=[[Scribd]] |author=Benjamin Tiven |date=2014-08-23 }} / also in the [http://www.servinglibrary.org/journal/3/falschungserschwerende-schrift servinglibrary] / and the layout in the [https://issuu.com/noorasharafi/docs/vis301_fa13_sharafi_noora_43406 fall issue of the magazin] The final publication in German law for the usage on license plates includes three variants – normal script ({{lang|de|Mittelschrift}}) with 75 mm high and 47.5 mm wide letters and 44.5 mm wide digits ({{convert|75|x|47.5|x|44.5|mm|in|frac=16|disp=out}}), narrow script ({{lang|de|Engschrift}}) with 75 mm high and 40.5 mm wide letters and 38.5 wide digits ({{convert|75|x|40.5|x|38.5|mm|in|frac=16|disp=out}}) and a small script ({{lang|de|verkleinerte Mittelschrift}}) with 49 mm high and 31 mm wide letters and 29 mm wide digits ({{convert|59|x|31|x|29|mm|in|frac=16|disp=out}}). The legal typeface includes [[diaeresis (diacritic)|umlaut vowels]] as these occur in German county codes at the start of the license plate number.see [[Vehicle registration plates of Germany]] The narrow font allows nine characters to be put on a standard Euro license plate — shorter numbers are supposed to be printed with larger spaces between characters as to fill the available space on the plate. The German law defines the font in "Anlage 4" (appendix 4) of the "Fahrzeugzulassungsverordnung" (vehicle admission ordinance).https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/fzv_2011/BJNR013900011.html In section 2.1 it shows three names for it as "fälschungserschwerende Schrift", "FE-Schrift" and „Schrift für Kfz-Kennzeichen“ (font for license plates) with the latter to be used for requesting templates from the "Bundesanstalt für Straßenwesen" (Federal Highway Research Institute / BASt). Digital variants have never been published by them but there exist third party digitilizations for free download, for example the font "Euro Plate".https://www.andyhoppe.com/design/fonts/euro-plate-font/ The Swiss foundry [[Lineto]] has published an extended script that covers the full range of Latin letters inspired by the FE Schrift under the names FE Mittelschrift and FE Engschrift.https://lineto.com/The+Fonts/Font+Categories/Headline+Fonts/FE/ == Adoption process == When the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} was finished in 1980 the pressure for its adoption had lessened already. Its distribution was furthered by another event being the introduction of the [[Vehicle registration plates of Europe|Euro license plate]]. With the fall of the [[iron curtain]] there was again a spike in the theft rate of license plates, including cars being stolen and moved to Eastern Europe. Again there was a motivation to prevent that with new regulations on license plates. In the new process the officials found the FE-Schrift which was fully developed and a perfect match for the [[automatic number-plate recognition]] technology that had developed to a usable state at the time. Some of the federal states in the eastern part of Germany introduced the new design during 1994 in anticipation of the national resolution.http://www.kennzeichen-guide.de/schilder/GeschichteD.htm In January 1995 it was introduced nationwide by a federal law that came to include the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} as well as it had been in the planning since the 1970s.{{cite web|url=http://www.bgbl.de/xaver/bgbl/start.xav?jumpTo=bgbl195s0008.pdf|title=Einunddzwanzigste Verordnung zur Änderung straßenverkehrsrechtlicher Vorschriften (21. ÄndVstVR)|date=1995-01-06|work=Bundesgesetzblatt Jahrgang 1995 Teil I Nr.1|quote=Einführung des Euro-Kennzeichens}} The shift in legislation matches with the first [[Schengen zone]] to lift borders during 1995. With the extension of the Schengen zone in 1998 the new license plate design found EU-wide acceptance (even for non-Schengen countries) thereby lifting the older requirement of adding an extra [[international license plate code|country code plate]] on the car when roaming to other countries which constitutes an advantage to citizens. Shortly later the option to be issued an old (non-Euro) license plate design were dropped on 1 November 2000{{cite web|url=http://www.bgbl.de/xaver/bgbl/start.xav?jumpTo=bgbl100s1090.pdf|title=Zweiunddreißigste Verordnung zur Änderung straßenverkehrsrechtlicher Vorschriften (32. ÄndVstVR)|date=2000-07-20|work=Bundesgesetzblatt Jahrgang 2000 Teil I Nr.34|pages=1093|quote=Artikel 13 (e) [..] Euro-Kennzeichen [..] spätestens ab dem 1. November 2000 [..] anzuwenden, die [..] mit einem neuen Kennzeichen ausgerüstet werden. Kennzeichen [..] in der vor diesem Termin geltenden Fassung [..] gelten weiter. [..] (f) Die Übergangsvorschrift §60 Abs. 1b (Einführung des Euro-Kennzeichens) wird aufgehoben.}} and the legislation dropped the older typeface for license plates alongside. The {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} is mandatory in Germany since that time although older license plates continue to be valid. There is an exception for historic cars to get a new license plate in the DIN typeface, and the {{lang|de|[[Bundeswehr]]}} armed forces continue to generally issue their plates in the DIN typeface. [[File:Flag_of_Europe.svg|thumb|The EU circle of stars distinguishes member states]] [[File:Flag_of_Mercosur.svg|thumb|The Mercosur emblem represents the Crux constellation (Southern Cross)]] Other countries have begun to introduce a forgery-impeding script as well, either taking over the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} or using a derivative variant. Taking over the original design, including the Euro license plate format, is generally cost effective – while in many countries the car license plates are produced by the state it is not the case in Germany. In Germany the car owner has to pay for a new license plate which gets a license stamp to be valid on the road (the round stamp is placed between county code and the local registration code). In the vicinity of the [[vehicle registration]] offices several small shops compete to press a license plate on the spot – their printing machines are highly standardized and the German license plate design is tailored to allow for cheap production in high quality.{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qvlIZfIcQKg |title=Maschinen und Werkzeuge zur Herstellung von gepägten Kfz-Kennzeichen |publisher=Autoschilder Sievers |date=2014-05-10 |language=de }}
/ dubbed as {{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J_UXLhMYR3o|title=Machines and tools for the assembly of automobile number plates |publisher=Autoschilder Sievers |date=2014-05-12 |language=en }} Specifically in Europe some countries started to adopt the style of [[Vehicle registration plates of the European Union|registration plates of the European Union]] even before becoming full members. The main difference is that EU registrations plates may bear a [[circle of stars]] as present in the [[Flag of Europe]]. The usage of stars is however completely optional and even after becoming a full member. The license plates may not need to be changed to be valid but new license plates may be issued with that hint to the EU membership. In October 2014 the members of the [[Mercosur]] South American trade bloc agreed to introduce a common design for license plates. The size of the license plates is similar to the EU license plates but only 40 cm wide on a regular basis. The design uses the narrow script "Engschrift" FE-Schrift design to show the registration code with 7 elements. The FE-Schrift was found to perform better against alteration and falsification in comparison to the Brasilian [[Mandatory (typeface)|Mandatory]] script as shown in a test at the [[Instituto Nacional de Tecnología Industrial|INTI]].{{cite web|url=https://www.inti.gob.ar/sabercomo/sc114/inti8.php|title=Nueva patente para los vehículos del Mercosur|work=Instituto Nacional de Tecnología Industrial (Buenos Aires)|date=August 2015|issue=114}} The design also includes a blue strip above the registration code with the Mercosur emblem in the left upper corner, the national flag of the member state in the right upper corner, and the country name printed in the center. It was agreed to introduce the Mercosur design by 2016.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=14stskFu1Ikhttp://en.mercopress.com/2014/10/09/mercosur-finally-agrees-unified-number-plates-for-new-cars-beginning-2016 The actual introduction was delayed until 2018. The early adoption in Africa is based on proposals against falsified and stolen license plates made by the German [[Utsch AG]], which had also developed the retroflective plates for Germany, and which was able to deliver the embossing machines for plates with FE-Schrift as they were already in mass production for the national market in 1994/95. In South Africa the empty license plates had been delivered with a special certification mark from the beginning, which would tell if a plate is authorized for embossing by licensed plate makers (today the certification mark contains a [[QR code]]).https://mybroadband.co.za/news/motoring/176749-number-plates-in-south-africa-what-you-can-and-cant-do.html In other regions the car owner will get a third "license plate mark" being a sticker for the front window that can not be removed non-destructively and where the sticker does also contain all the license plate information (some of latest variants even integrate an RFID chip containing the information).{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/mobilitaet/2014-04/autokennzeichen-rfid|title=Schlaue Schilder|work=Die Zeit|date=2014-04-04|language=de}} == Usage == {{section refimprove|date=April 2018}} * On Euro-style license plates with the country code in a blue section on the left: ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Germany|Germany]] – introduced in 1995 on Euro license plates only, these are mandatory since 2000 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] – in 2009 the new Euro-style license plate design was introduced along with the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} typeface. The new design (dropping the national crest from the old Euro-style license plates as it was used since 1998) is more similar to the Euro license plate. ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Malta|Malta]] – since 2004, the Euro-style license plate design was introduced in 1995 without the FE-Scrift ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Cyprus|Cyprus]] – since 3 June 2013 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Georgia (country)|Georgia]] – since 3 June 2013 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Latvia|Latvia]] - only for tractors and tractor trailers. On car, car trailer and motorcycle plates they use [[DIN 1451]].http://avto-nomer.ru/newforum/index.php?app=forums&module=forums&controller=topic&id=9152 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Cuba|Cuba]] resolved a law on a new license plate scheme in 2013 which opted for the Euro license plate format and the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}}. The reasoning is to lower the cost while increasing the quality of the plates with the change to be completed by May 2016.{{cite web |url=https://cubaheute.wordpress.com/2013/05/22/kuba-modernisiert-seine-kfz-kennzeichen/ |title=Kuba modernisiert seine Kfz-Kennzeichen |date=2013-05-22 |author=Marcel Kunzmann |publisher=Cuba Heute }} ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Moldova|Moldova]] – since 1 April 2015 * Common design in [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] countries with a region code section along with the country name / flag: ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Uzbekistan|Uzbekistan]] – since 2009 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Armenia|Armenia]] – since 2014 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Kyrgyzstan|Kyrgyzstan]] – since 2016 * Common design of Mercosur countries with the country name in a blue strip above the number: ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Uruguay|Uruguay]] – the old numbering scheme with three digits was exhausted in 2001 leading to a new scheme in 2002 in Montevideo which included four digits and came to use the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} as well. The new license plate design is mandatory for Uruguay since 2011. Uruguay did pick up the blue strip of the Mercosur design by March 2015 for new license plates. ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Argentina|Argentina]] – using the Mercosur design since 2016 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Paraguay|Paraguay]] - using the Mercosur design for new cars by 2016, other registrations may use it by 2018 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Brazil|Brazil]] - using the Mercosur design since September 2018, first state was [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]] ** with introduction date in the former Mercosur member state [[Vehicle registration plates of Venezuela|Venezuela]] being unknown (membership suspended since 2016) * Countries in Africa: ** [[Vehicle registration plates of South Africa|South Africa]] – the numbering scheme and license plate design were changed in 1994 which did also introduce the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}}. ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Namibia|Namibia]] since 1994, following south-african style but with new registration codes that start with "N" ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Tanzania|Tanzania]] started to introduce a new design in the 1990s using {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}}, registration codes start with "T" ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Uganda|Uganda]] since 1999, registration codes start with "U" ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Sierra Leone|Sierra Leone]] - probably since 1999 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Botswana|Botswana]] probably around 2000, registration codes start with "B" ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Mozambique|Mozambique]] probably around 2000, registration codes start with "M" ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Zambia|Zambia]] since 2000 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Ethiopia|Ethiopia]] - probably since 2002, only numbers ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Cameroon|Cameroon]] since 2005 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe]] since 2006 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Rwanda|Rwanda]] since 2007, registration codes start with "R" ** [[Vehicle registration plates of South Sudan|South Sudan]] - probably since 2007, initially only used on government vehicles{{cite news |url=http://www.gurtong.net/ECM/Editorial/tabid/124/ctl/ArticleView/mid/519/articleId/18467/South-Sudan-To-Have-Unified-Number-Plates-For-Cars.aspx |title=South Sudan to have unified number plates for cars |work=Gurtong |date=4 February 2016 |accessdate=2 October 2016 }} ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Mali|Mali]] - probably since 2008 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]] since 2009 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Burundi|Burundi]] – since April 2009 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Malawi|Malawi]] - probably since 2011 * Other countries: ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Sri Lanka|Sri Lanka]] – since August 2000, with a variation of the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} developed by a German company ** [[Vehicle registration plates of the United Arab Emirates|Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates]] - probably since 2006, only numbers ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Sierra Leone|Sierra Leone]] - since 2007 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Kuwait|Kuwait]] - probably since 2007, only numbers ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Guatemala|Guatemala]] - probably since 2008 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Bahrain|Bahrain]] - since 2010 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Peru|Peru]] – since 2010 ** [[Vehicle registration plates of Colombia|Colombia]] - since 2016 only for diplomatic cars ** [[Vehicle registration plates of the Philippines|Philippines]] - Since February 2018, used for personalized plates since 2010. [[File:Tablica KR - Kranj.jpg|thumb|Euro license plate in Slovenia with a similar typeface using some FE-Schrift characteristics]] Some countries allow the {{lang|de|FE-Schrift}} as an alternative to the standard typeface especially in combination with a Euro-style license plate. Some license plates in [[Vehicle registration plates of Ghana|Ghana]] have been issued using an FE-Schrift style. In [[Vehicle registration plates of Australia#V Plates Personalised Plates|Australia personalized plates]] may be issued with an FE-Schrift using a special design of vanity plates. Some countries have developed a typeface for license plates with similar features: [[Vehicle registration plates of Albania|Albania]] since 2002, [[Vehicle registration plates of Georgia (country)|Georgia]] since 2014, [[Vehicle registration plates of Guinea|Guinea]], [[Vehicle registration plates of New Zealand|New Zealand]], [[Vehicle registration plates of Netherlands|Netherlands]], [[Vehicle registration plates of Serbia|Serbia]], [[Vehicle registration plates of Slovenia|Slovenia]] (2004–2008), == Examples == {{example farm|section|date=September 2018}} File:KFZmod.png|Germany (since 1994) File:2013 Cyprus sample licence plate.png|Cyprus (since 2013) File:License plate Bosnia and Herzegowina 2009.jpg|Bosnia and Herzegovina File:License plate of Cuba 2013 Las Tunas T 003 526.jpg|Cuba File:ACF 110.jpg|Malta File:KFZ-SA-Limpopo.jpg|South Africa File:2005 Victoria registration plate V BL 321 europlate.jpg|Australia – Victoria (vanity plate) File:Matrícula automovilística argentina 2016 (Mercosur)-B.png|Argentina File:Matrícula automovilística Uruguay 2016 ABC 1234 Mercosur.jpg|Uruguay File:Placa_de_veículo_Brasil_2018_A0B1CD2_Mercosul.jpg|Brazil File:FE-Schrift Colombian diplomatic service licence plate.jpg|Colombia (diplomatic car) File:Pelak_shakhsi-UZ.png|Uzbekistan File:Plak-Shakhsi-AM.png|Armenia File:Plak_shakhsi-KG.png|Kyrgyzstan File:Congo_license_plate_graphic.png|Congo File:Namibian license plates.JPG|Namibia File:Tanzania private vehicle registration plate FE-Schrift.jpg|Tanzania File:Philippine license plates LTO.jpg|Philippines (Current license plates issued by the Land Transportation Office) == See also == * [[Mandatory (typeface)]] * [[Vehicle registration plates of Germany]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Government typefaces]] [[Category:Sans-serif typefaces]] [[Category:Vehicle registration plates]]
