[[Bloomsbury Publishing]] (Australia) | keypeople = | publications = Books | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = {{URL|https://www.versobooks.com/}} }} '''Verso Books''' (formerly '''New Left Books''') is a publishing house based in London and New York City, founded in 1970 by the staff of ''[[New Left Review]]''. ==Renaming, new brand and logo== Verso Books was originally known as New Left Books. The name "Verso" refers to the technical term for the left-hand page in a book (see [[recto and verso]]), and is a play on words regarding its political outlook and also reminds of the [[vice versa]] - "the other way around". ==History and details== The publisher gained early recognition for translations of books by European thinkers, especially those from the [[Frankfurt School]]. Verso Books' best-selling title is the autobiography of [[Rigoberta Menchú]], who was awarded the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 1992.Verso Books, [http://www.versobooks.com/pg/about-verso About Verso] Verso Books titles are distributed in the United States by [[Random House]]. On April 8, 2014 Verso began bundling [[DRM-free]] e-books with print purchases made through its website. Verso's managing director Jacob Stevens stated that he expected the new offer on the Verso website to contribute £200,000 to the publisher's revenue in its first year helping to "shake up how publishers relate to their readership, and help to support independent publishing".{{cite web|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/e-bookprint-bundling-venture-verso|title=E-book/print bundling venture from Verso |publisher=thebookseller.com}} == See also == * [[List of Radical Thinkers releases]] * [[New Left Review]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|https://www.versobooks.com/}} [[Category:Book publishing companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Book publishing companies based in New York (state)]] [[Category:Political book publishing companies]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1970]] [[Category:1970 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:1970 establishments in England]] [[Category:American companies established in 1970]] {{publish-corp-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Wendell Berry | image = A New Harvest, with Wendell Berry, Henry County, KY, 2011 - photograph by Guy Mendes (cropped).jpg | image_size = | caption = Berry in December 2011 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1934|8|5}} | birth_place = [[Henry County, Kentucky]], U.S. | occupation = Poet, farmer, writer, activist, academic | nationality = American | period = | genre = Fiction, poetry, essays | subject = Agriculture, rural life, community | education = [[University of Kentucky]] (B.A, 1956; M.A., 1957) }} '''Wendell Erdman Berry''' (born August 5, 1934) is an American novelist, poet, [[environmental activist]], [[cultural critic]], and farmer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neh.gov/about/awards/jefferson-lecture/wendell-e-berry-biography |title=Wendell E. Berry biography |publisher=National Endowment for the Humanities |accessdate=April 26, 2015}}</ref> He is an elected member of the [[Fellowship of Southern Writers]], a recipient of [[The National Humanities Medal]], and the [[Jefferson Lecture]]r for 2012. He is also a 2013 Fellow of [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences|The American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]. Berry was named the recipient of the 2013 [[Dayton Literary Peace Prize|Richard C. Holbrooke Distinguished Achievement Award]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Dayton Literary Peace Prize names distinguished achievement award recipient |url=http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/entertainment/books-literature/dayton-literary-peace-prize-names-distinguished-ac/nZMCj/ |publisher=[[Dayton Daily News]] |date=August 12, 2013 |accessdate=August 12, 2013}}</ref> On January 28, 2015, he became the first living writer to be inducted into the Kentucky Writers Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Eblen |first1=Tom |title=At Hall of Fame ceremony, Wendell Berry laments 'public silence' on Ky. writers' work |url=http://www.kentucky.com/2015/01/31/3671526_tom-eblen-at-hall-of-fame-ceremony.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |date=January 31, 2015}}</ref>
==Life== Berry was the first of four children born to John Marshall Berry, a lawyer and tobacco farmer in [[Henry County, Kentucky]], and Virginia Erdman Berry. The families of both parents had farmed in Henry County for at least five generations. Berry attended secondary school at [[Millersburg Military Institute]] and then earned a B.A. (1956) and M.A. (1957) in English at the [[University of Kentucky]].<ref name=PWNS-2018/>{{rp|990–991}} In 1956, at the University of Kentucky he met another Kentucky writer-to-be, [[Gurney Norman]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://community.berea.edu/appalachianheritage/issues/summer2005/conversation.html |title=My Conversation with Gurney Norman |first=Wendell |last=Berry |publisher= |date= |accessdate=July 30, 2010}}</ref> He completed his M.A. and married Tanya Amyx in 1957. In 1958, he attended [[Stanford University]]'s creative writing program as a [[Wallace Stegner]] Fellow, studying under Stegner in a seminar that included [[Larry McMurtry]], [[Robert Stone (novelist)|Robert Stone]], [[Ernest Gaines]], [[Tillie Olsen]], and [[Ken Kesey]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Menand |first=Louis |url=http://www.newyorker.com/arts/critics/atlarge/2009/06/08/090608crat_atlarge_menand?currentPage=4 |title=Show or Tell: A Critic at Large: The New Yorker |publisher=The New Yorker |date=January 7, 2009 |accessdate=July 13, 2009}}</ref><ref name="Angyal-1995">{{cite book |last=Angyal|first=Andrew|title=Wendell Berry|location=New York|publisher=Twayne|year=1995|isbn=0-8057-4628-5}}</ref>{{RP|139}} Berry's first novel, ''Nathan Coulter'', was published in April 1960.
A [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation]] Fellowship took Berry and his family to Italy and France in 1961, where he came to know [[Wallace Fowlie]], critic and translator of French literature. From 1962 to 1964, he taught English at [[New York University]]'s University Heights campus in [[the Bronx]]. In 1964, he began teaching creative writing at the [[University of Kentucky]], from which he resigned in 1977.<ref name="Angyal-1995" /> During this time in Lexington, he came to know author [[Guy Davenport]], as well as author and monk [[Thomas Merton]] and photographer [[Ralph Eugene Meatyard]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Davenport |first=Guy |chapter=Tom and Gene |title=Father Louie: Photographs of Thomas Merton by Ralph Eugene Meatyard |location=New York |publisher=Timken |year=1991 |isbn=978-0943221090}}</ref>
On July 4, 1965, Berry, his wife, and his two children moved to a farm that he had purchased, Lane's Landing, and began growing corn and small grains on what eventually became a homestead of about 117 acres (0.47 km<sup>2</sup>).<ref name=PWNS-2018>{{Cite book|title=Wendell Berry: Port William Novels & Stories, The Civil War to World War II|last=Berry|first=Wendell|publisher=Library of America|year=2018|isbn=9781598535549|location=New York}}</ref>{{RP|994}} They bought their first flock of seven Border Cheviot sheep in 1978.<ref name=PWNS-2018/>{{rp|998}} Lane's Landing is in [[Henry County, Kentucky]] in north central Kentucky near [[Port Royal, Kentucky|Port Royal]], and his parents' birthplaces, and is on the western bank of the [[Kentucky River]], not far from where it flows into the [[Ohio River]]. Berry has farmed, resided, and written at Lane's Landing ever since. He has written about his early experiences on the land and about his decision to return to it in essays such as "The Long-Legged House" and "A Native Hill."<ref>Both were published in ''The Long-Legged House.'' New York: Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich, 1969 (Shoemaker & Hoard, 2004). {{ISBN|9781593760137}}</ref>
In the 1970s and the early 1980s, he edited and wrote for the [[Rodale Press]], including its publications ''Organic Gardening and Farming'' and ''The New Farm''. From 1987 to 1993, he returned to the English Department of the University of Kentucky.<ref name="Angyal-1995"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://quiviracoalition.org/images/category/459-2007Conference_Program_Web.pdf |title=The Quivira Coalition's 6th Annual Conference |page=14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151203130354/http://quiviracoalition.org/images/category/459-2007Conference_Program_Web.pdf |archivedate=December 3, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Berry has written at least twenty-five books (or [[chapbook]]s) of poems, sixteen volumes of essays, and eleven novels and short story collections. His writing is grounded in the notion that one's work ought to be rooted in and responsive to one's place.
Berry, who describes himself as "a person who takes the Gospel seriously,"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/wendell-berry/ |title=The Brian Lehrer Show |publisher=WNYC.org |date=October 17, 2013 |quote=I'm not a Baptist in any formal way. I go to the Baptist church, where my wife plays the piano, on days of bad weather. On days of good weather, I ramble off into the woods somewhere. I am a person who takes the Gospel seriously, but I have had trouble conforming my thoughts to a denomination.}}</ref> has criticized Christian organizations for failing to challenge cultural complacency about environmental degradation,<ref>{{cite book |last=Berry |first=Wendell |chapter=Christianity and the Survival of Creation |title=Sex, Economy, Freedom & Community |location=New York |publisher=Pantheon |year=1993 |isbn=9780679423942}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2006/november/32.60.html?start=1 |title=Christianity Today, 15 November 2006 "Imagining a Different Way to Live" | quote= The church and all of our institutions have failed to oppose the destruction of the world.}}</ref> and has shown a willingness to criticize what he perceives as the arrogance of some Christians.<ref>{{cite web |quote=Well, Christendom is all right, but it doesn't have to exclude everybody else. It doesn't have to go to war against them. And it doesn't have to be so stupid as to condemn other faiths that it doesn't know anything about |first=Rose Marie |last=Berger |url=https://sojo.net/magazine/july-2004/web-exclusive-wendell-berry-interview-complete-text |title=Web Exclusive: A Sojourner Interview with Wendell Berry |date=July 2004}}</ref> He is an advocate of [[Christian pacifism]], as shown in his book ''Blessed Are the Peacemakers: [[Christ]]'s Teachings About Love, Compassion and Forgiveness'' (2005).
Berry is a fellow of [[United Kingdom|Britain]]'s [[Temenos Academy]], a learned society devoted to the study of all faiths and spiritual pursuits; Berry publishes frequently in the annual ''[[Temenos Academy Review]]'', funded by the [[Prince of Wales]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.temenosacademy.org/temenos_key_individuals.html |title=Key Individuals of The Temenos Academy |work=Temenosacademy.org |date=2009 |accessdate=July 13, 2009}}</ref>
==Activism== On February 10, 1968, Berry delivered "A Statement Against the War in Vietnam" during the Kentucky Conference on the War and the Draft at the [[University of Kentucky]] in Lexington:<ref>Berry, Wendell. ''The Long-Legged House.'' Washington, D.C.: Shoemaker & Hoard, 2004. p.64</ref>
{{quote|We seek to preserve peace by fighting a war, or to advance freedom by subsidizing dictatorships, or to 'win the hearts and minds of the people' by poisoning their crops and burning their villages and confining them in concentration camps; we seek to uphold the 'truth' of our cause with lies, or to answer conscientious dissent with threats and slurs and intimidations. . . . I have come to the realization that I can no longer imagine a war that I would believe to be either useful or necessary. I would be against any war.<ref name=Vance>{{cite web |last=Vance |first=Laurence |date=December 4, 2006 |url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/vance/vance98.html |title=Bill Kauffman: American Anarchist |work=[[LewRockwell.com]]}}</ref>}}
On June 3, 1979, Berry engaged in nonviolent [[civil disobedience]] against the construction of a [[Marble Hill Nuclear Power Plant|nuclear power plant at Marble Hill, Indiana]]. He describes "this nearly eventless event" and expands upon his reasons for it in the essay "The Reactor and the Garden."<ref>Berry, Wendell. ''The Gift of Good Land.'' Berkeley: Counterpoint, 2009. pp.161–170</ref>
On February 9, 2003, Berry's essay titled "A Citizen's Response to the National Security Strategy of the United States" was published as a full-page advertisement in ''The New York Times''. Berry opened the essay—a critique of the [[George W. Bush|G. W. Bush]] administration's [[post-9/11]] international strategy<ref>{{cite web |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/nsc/nss/2002/ |title=The National Security Strategy 2002 |date=November 4, 2007 |work=archives.gov |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>—by asserting that "The new National Security Strategy published by the White House in September 2002, if carried out, would amount to a radical revision of the political character of our nation."<ref>{{cite web |first=Wedell |last=Berry |url=http://www.orionmagazine.org/index.php/articles/article/20/ |title=A Citizen's Response to the National Security Strategy |work=[[Orion (magazine)|Orion]] |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
On January 4, 2009, Berry and [[Wes Jackson]], president of [[Land Institute|The Land Institute]], published an op-ed article in ''The New York Times'' titled "A 50-Year Farm Bill."<ref name="nytimes2009">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/05/opinion/05berry.html |last1=Jackson |first1=Wes |first2=Wendell |last2=Berry |title=A 50-Year Farm Bill |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 5, 2009 |subscription=yes}}</ref> In July 2009 Berry, Jackson and Fred Kirschenmann, of The Leopold Center for Sustainable Agriculture, gathered in Washington DC to promote this idea.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/21/AR2009072100645.html |title=Q&A: Changing Farming's Uncertain Future |date=July 22, 2009 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> Berry and Jackson wrote, "We need a 50-year farm bill that addresses forthrightly the problems of soil loss and degradation, toxic pollution, fossil-fuel dependency and the destruction of rural communities."<ref name="nytimes2009"/>
Also in January 2009, Berry released a statement against the death penalty, which began, "As I am made deeply uncomfortable by the taking of a human life before birth, I am also made deeply uncomfortable by the taking of a human life after birth."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://danzigusa.blogspot.com/2009/01/wendell-berry-makes-public-statement-on.html |title=Wendell Berry Makes Public Statement on the Death Penalty |date=January 29, 2009 |work=Danzig U.S.A. |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> And in November 2009, Berry and 38 other writers from Kentucky wrote to [[Steve Beshear|Gov. Steve Beshear]] and [[Jack Conway (politician)|Attorney General Jack Conway]] asking them to impose a moratorium on the death penalty in that state.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kcadp.org/2009/11/25/kentucky-writers-urge-moratorium-on-death-penalty/ |title=Kentucky writers urge moratorium on death penalty |date=November 25, 2009 |work=Kentucky Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
On March 2, 2009, Berry joined over 2,000 others in non-violently blocking the gates to a coal-fired power plant in Washington, D.C. No one was arrested.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.democracynow.org/2009/3/3/headlines#5 |title=Climate Activists Block Gates to D.C. Coal Plant |date=March 3, 2009 |work=[[Democracy Now!]] |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
On May 22, 2009, Berry, at a listening session in Louisville, spoke against the [[National Animal Identification System]] (NAIS).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rc2xTRww3WE |title=NAIS Comments}}</ref> He said, "If you impose this program on the small farmers, who are already overburdened, you're going to have to send the police for me. I'm 75 years old. I've about completed my responsibilities to my family. I'll lose very little in going to jail in opposition to your program – and I'll have to do it. Because I will be, in every way that I can conceive of, a non-cooperator."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foodrenegade.com/wendell-berry-picks-jail-over-nais/ |title=Wendell Berry Picks Jail Over NAIS |first=Kristen |last=Michaelis |work=Food Renegade |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
In October 2009, Berry combined with "the Berea-based Kentucky Environmental Foundation (KEF), along with several other non-profit organizations and rural electric co-op members" to petition against and protest the construction of a coal-burning power plant in [[Clark County, Kentucky]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://richmondregister.com/localnews/x546340377/Local-group-joins-protest-of-coal-burning-power-plant |title=Local group joins protest of coal-burning power plant |first=Ronica |last=Shannon |date=November 7, 2009 |newspaper=[[Richmond Register]] |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> On February 28, 2011, the Kentucky Public Service Commission approved the cancellation of this power plant.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://migration.kentucky.gov/Newsroom/psc/pscpr2-28-2011.htm |title=PSC approves EKPC request to cancel power plant |first=Andrew |last=Melnykovych |work=Commonwealth of Kentucky |date=February 28, 2011 |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
On December 20, 2009, due to the University of Kentucky's close association with coal interests in the state, Berry removed his papers from the university. He explained to the Lexington Herald-Leader, "I don't think the University of Kentucky can be so ostentatiously friendly to the coal industry … and still be a friend to me and the interests for which I have stood for the last 45 years. … If they love the coal industry that much, I have to cancel my friendship."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kentucky.com/2010/06/23/1319383_wendell-berry-pulling-his-personal.html?rh=1 |title=Wendell Berry pulling his personal papers from UK |first=Cheryl |last=Truman |date=June 23, 2010 |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> In August 2012, the papers were donated to The Kentucky Historical Society in Frankfort, KY.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kentucky.com/2012/08/15/2300331/author-wendell-berry-donates-papers.html |title=Author Wendell Berry donates papers to Kentucky Historical Society |first=Cheryl |last=Truman |date=August 15, 2012 |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
On September 28, 2010, Berry participated in a rally in Louisville during an EPA hearing on how to manage coal ash. Berry said, "The EPA knows that coal ash is poison. We ask it only to believe in its own findings on this issue, and do its duty."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://irjci.blogspot.com/2010/09/environmentalists-and-industry.html |title=Environmentalists and industry supporters turn out for Louisville coal ash hearing |first=Jon |last=Hale |date=September 29, 2010 |work=The Rural Blog |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
Berry, with 14 other protesters, spent the weekend of February 12, 2011 locked in the Kentucky governor's office to demand an end to [[mountaintop removal mining|mountaintop removal coal mining]]. He was part of the environmental group [[Kentuckians for the Commonwealth]] that began their sit-in on Friday and left at midday Monday to join about 1,000 others in a mass outdoor rally.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.democracynow.org/2011/2/14/headlines/opponents_on_mountaintop_removal_occupy_kentucky_governors_office |title=Opponents of Mountaintop Removal Coal Mining Occupy Kentucky Governor's Office |date=February 14, 2011 |work=Democracy Now! |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.kentucky.com/news/politics-government/article44079546.html |title=Sit-in at Kentucky governor's office ends with 'I Love Mountains' rally |first=John |last=Cheves |work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
In 2011, The Berry Center was established at [[New Castle, Kentucky]], "for the purpose of bringing focus, knowledge and cohesiveness to the work of changing our ruinous industrial agriculture system into a system and culture that uses nature as the standard, accepts no permanent damage to the ecosphere, and takes into consideration human health in local communities."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.berrycenter.org/ |title=The Berry Center |work=berrycenter.org |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
==Ideas== Berry's [[nonfiction]] serves as an extended conversation about the life he values. According to him, the good life includes sustainable agriculture, [[appropriate technology|appropriate technologies]], healthy rural [[community|communities]], connection to place, the pleasures of good food, [[husbandry]], good work, local economics, the [[miracle]] of life, fidelity, [[frugality]], reverence, and the interconnectedness of life. The threats Berry finds to this good [[simple living|simple life]] include: [[industrial farming]] and the industrialization of life, ignorance, hubris, greed, violence against others and against the [[nature|natural world]], the eroding [[topsoil]] in the United States, [[globalization|global economics]], and [[Natural environment|environmental destruction]]. As a prominent defender of agrarian values, Berry's appreciation for traditional farming techniques, such as those of the [[Amish]], grew in the 1970s, due in part to exchanges with ''Draft Horse Journal'' publisher [[Maurice Telleen]]. Berry has long been friendly to and supportive of [[Wes Jackson]], believing that Jackson's agricultural research at The [[Land Institute]] lives out the promise of "solving for pattern" and using "nature as model."
Author [[Rod Dreher]] writes that Berry's "unshakable devotion to the land, to [[Localism (politics)|localism]], and to the dignity of traditional life makes him both a great American and, to the disgrace of our age, a prophet without honor in his native land."<ref name=Dreher>{{cite web |url=http://www.theamericanconservative.com/articles/all-american-anarchists/ |title=All-American Anarchists |first=Rod |last=Dreher |authorlink=Rod Dreher |work=[[The American Conservative]] |date=June 5, 2006 |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> Similarly, [[Bill Kauffman]] argues that "Among the tragedies of contemporary politics is that Wendell Berry, as a man of place, has no place in a national political discussion that is framed by [[Gannett Company|Gannett]] and [[Clear Channel Communications|Clear Channel]]."<ref name=Dreher /> Historian [[Richard White (historian)|Richard White]] calls Berry "the environmental writer who has most thoughtfully tried to come to terms with labor" and "one of the few environmental writers who takes work seriously."<ref>{{cite book |last=White |first=Richard |chapter='Are You an Environmentalist or Do You Work for a Living?': Work and Nature |title=Uncommon Ground: Rethinking the Human Place in Nature |editor-first=William |editor-last=Cronon |location=New York |publisher=Norton |year=1995 |page=179 |isbn=9780393038729}}</ref>
The concept of "''Solving for pattern''", coined by Berry in his essay<ref>{{cite book |last=Berry |first=Wendell |title=The Gift of Good Land: Further Essays Cultural and Agricultural |location=San Francisco |publisher=North Point |year=1981 |isbn=0-86547-052-9}}</ref> of the same title, is the process of finding solutions that solve multiple problems, while minimizing the creation of new problems. The essay was originally published in the [[Rodale Press]] periodical ''The New Farm''. Though Mr. Berry's use of the phrase was in direct reference to agriculture, it has since come to enjoy broader use throughout the design community.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eoearth.org/view/article/156584/ |title=The designer's challenge |first=David |last=Orr |work=eoearth.org |date=April 16, 2008 |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.di.net/articles/solving-for-pattern-development-of-place-building-design-models/ |title=Solving for Pattern: Development of Place-Building Design Models |first=Stephen |last=Luoni |work=DesignIntelligence |date=December 21, 2005 |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
Berry's core ideas, and in particular his poem "Sabbaths III (Santa Clara Valley)," guided the 2007 documentary feature film ''[[The Unforeseen (film)|The Unforeseen]]'', produced by [[Terrence Malick]] and [[Robert Redford]].<ref>The poem has been published only in the limited edition chapbook ''Sabbaths 1987''. (Monterey, Kentucky: Larkspur, 1991).</ref> The film's director [[Laura Dunn (film director)|Laura Dunn]] stated, "We are of course most grateful to Mr. Berry for sharing his inspired work – his poem served as a guide post for me throughout this, at times meandering, project."<ref>[http://streams.twobirdsfilm.com/2007/07/09/wendell-berrys-poem-santa-clara-valley/ Wendell Berry's poem "Santa Clara Valley" ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427190543/http://streams.twobirdsfilm.com/2007/07/09/wendell-berrys-poem-santa-clara-valley/ |date=April 27, 2011 }}</ref> Berry appears in the film narrating his own poem.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2007/film/markets-festivals/the-unforeseen-1200510729/ |title=The Unforeseen |first=Robert |last=Koehler |date=January 30, 2007 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=January 13, 2018}}</ref> Dunn went on to make the 2016 documentary feature ''Look & See: A Portrait of Wendell Berry'', again produced by Malick and Redford.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/2017/02_programm_2017/02_Filmdatenblatt_2017_201711861.php#tab=video |title=Look & See: A Portrait of Wendell Berry |publisher=[[Berlin International Film Festival]] |date=2017 |accessdate=January 13, 2018}}</ref>
==Poetry==
Berry's [[Lyric poetry|lyric]] poetry often appears as a contemporary [[eclogue]], [[pastoral]], or [[elegy]]; but he also composes dramatic and historical [[Narrative poetry|narratives]] (such as "Bringer of Water"<ref>''Farming: A Hand Book''. New York: Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich, 1970.</ref> and "July, 1773",<ref>''A Part''. San Francisco: North Point, 1980.</ref> respectively) and occasional and discursive poems ("Against the War in Vietnam"<ref>''Openings''. New York: Harcourt, Brace, 1968.</ref> and "Some Further Words",<ref>''Given: New Poems''. Washington D. C.: Shoemaker & Hoard. 2005.</ref> respectively).
Berry's first published poetry book consisted of a single poem, the elegiac ''November Twenty Six Nineteen Hundred Sixty Three'' (1964), initiated and illustrated by [[Ben Shahn]], commemorating the death of [[John F. Kennedy]]. It begins,
<poem>We know The winter earth Upon the body Of the young    President,    And the early dark    Falling;</poem>
and continues through ten more stanzas (each propelled by the [[Anaphora (rhetoric)|anaphora]] of "We know"). The elegiac here and elsewhere, according to Triggs, enables Berry to characterize the connections "that link past and future generations through their common working of the land."<ref>{{cite web |url= https://rucore.libraries.rutgers.edu/rutgers-lib/46714/PDF/1/ |title=Moving the Dark to Wholeness: The Elegies of Wendell Berry |first=Jeffery A. |last=Triggs |work=Rutgers University Libraries |year=1988 |accessdate=August 22, 2015 |doi=10.7282/T3QZ2CQ0}}</ref>
The first full-length collection, ''The Broken Ground'' (1964), develops many of Berry's fundamental concerns: "the cycle of life and death, responsiveness to place, pastoral subject matter, and recurring images of the Kentucky River and the hill farms of north-central Kentucky"<ref name="Angyal-1995"/>{{RP|119}}
According to Angyal, "There is little modernist formalism or postmodernist experimentation in [Berry's] verse."<ref name="Angyal-1995"/>{{RP|116}} A commitment to the reality and primacy of the actual world stands behind these two rejections. In "Notes: Unspecializing Poetry," Berry writes, "Devotion to order that is not poetical prevents the specialization of poetry."<ref>Berry, Wendell. ''Standing by Words''. San Francisco: North Point, 1983, p.80.</ref> He goes on to note, "Nothing exists for its own sake, but for a harmony greater than itself which includes it. A work of art, which accepts this condition, and exists upon its terms, honors the Creation, and so becomes a part of it" <ref>Berry, Wendell. ''Standing by Words''. San Francisco: North Point, 1983, p.85.</ref>
[[Lionel Basney]] placed Berry's poetry within a tradition of [[Didacticism|didactic poetry]] that stretches back to [[Horace]]: "To say that Berry's poetry can be didactic, then, means that it envisions a specific wisdom, and also the traditional sense of art and culture that gives art the task of teaching this wisdom"<ref>Basney, Lionel. 175. "Five Notes on the Didactic Tradition, in Praise of Wendell Berry" in Paul Merchant, editor. ''Wendell Berry'' (American Authors Series). Lewiston, Idaho: Confluence, 1991. pp.174–183.</ref>
For Berry, poetry exists "at the center of a complex reminding"<ref>Berry, Wendell. "The Responsibility of the Poet." ''What Are People For?'' New York: North Point, 1990. p.88.</ref> Both the poet and the reader are reminded of the poem's crafted language, of the poem's formal literary antecedents, of "what is remembered or ought to be remembered," and of "the formal integrity of other works, creatures and structures of the world.".<ref>Berry, Wendell. "The Responsibility of the Poet." ''What Are People For?'' New York: North Point, 1990. p.89.</ref>
=== The Sabbath Poems === From 1979 to the present Berry has been writing what he calls "[[Sabbath]] poems." They were first collected in ''A Timbered Choir: The Sabbath Poems 1979-1997''. This was followed by Sabbaths from 1998 to 2004 in ''Given: New Poems''; and those from 2005 to 2008 are in ''Leavings''. All Sabbath poems through 2012 are published in ''This Day: New and Collected Sabbath Poems 1979 - 2012''. ''Sabbaths 2013'' has been published by [[Larkspur Press]]. ''A Small Porch'' contains nine Sabbath poems from 2014 and sixteen from 2015. One Sabbath poem, "What Passes, What Remains" (VIII from 2016), is published as the epilogue in ''The Art of Loading Brush''. That poem, along with fourteen others, can also be found in ''Sabbaths 2016'', published by Larkspur Press.
The poems are motivated by Berry's longtime habit of walking out onto the land on Sunday mornings. As he puts it, "I go free from the tasks and intentions of my workdays, and so my mind becomes hospitable to unintended thoughts: to what I am very willing to call inspiration."<ref>{{Cite book|title=This Day: Collected and New Sabbath Poems|last=Berry|first=Wendell|publisher=Counterpoint|year=2013|isbn=978-1-61902-198-3|location=Berkeley, CA|pages=xxi}}</ref> He writes in a poem from 1979, <poem>The bell calls in the town Where forebears cleared the shaded land And brought high daylight down To shine on field and trodden road. I hear, but understand Contrarily, and walk into the woods. I leave labor and load, Take up a different story. I keep an inventory Of wonders and of uncommercial goods.<ref>{{Cite book|title=This Day: Collected & New Sabbath Poems|last=Berry|first=Wendell|publisher=Counterpoint|year=2013|isbn=978-1-61902-198-3|location=Berkeley|pages=11}}</ref></poem>The Sabbath poems have been described as "written from a particular place and on particular Sabbaths, and so should be read as part of a spiritual practice and as poems, in some sense, devoted to dwelling, to living thoughtfully in one place."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hudson|first=Marc|date=Winter 2015|title=Instantaneous and Eternal: Wendell Berry's Sabbath Poems|url=|journal=Sewanee Review|volume=123|pages=182–191|via=Project MUSE}}</ref> Oehlschlaeger links Berry's project to a key observation by [[Henry David Thoreau]],
<blockquote>As Thoreau continues in '[[Life Without Principle]],' he notes the constant busyness of Americans, so engaged in 'infinite bustle' that 'there is no sabbath.' And he notes later that 'there is nothing, not even crime, more opposed to poetry, to philosophy, ay, to life itself, than this incessant business.' The logic is clear: destruction of the Sabbath is contrary to 'life itself.' That, I suggest, is the context in which we should read the Sabbath poems that Berry has been writing for nearly the last thirty years.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Achievement of Wendell Berry: The Hard History of Love|last=Oehlschlaeger|first=Fritz|publisher=U P of Kentucky|year=2011|isbn=978-0-8131-3007-1|location=Lexington, KY|pages=37}}</ref></blockquote>
==Fiction==
Berry's fiction to date consists of eight novels and fifty-one short stories (forty-three of which are collected in ''That Distant Land'', 2004 and ''A Place in Time'', 2012) which, when read as a whole, form a chronicle of the fictional small Kentucky town of [[Port William, Kentucky|Port William]]. Because of his long-term, ongoing exploration of the life of an imagined place, Berry has been compared to [[William Faulkner]].<ref>Goodrich, Janet. ''The Unforeseen Self in the Works of Wendell Berry.'' University of Missouri Press, 2001. p.21.</ref> Yet, although Port William is no stranger to murder, suicide, alcoholism, marital discord, and the full range of losses that touch human lives, it lacks the extremes of characterization and plot development that are found in much of Faulkner. Hence Berry is sometimes described as working in an idealized, pastoral, or nostalgic mode, a characterization of his work which he resists: "If your work includes a criticism of history, which mine certainly does, you can't be accused of wanting to go back to something, because you're saying that what we were wasn't good enough." <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thesunmagazine.org/issues/218/field-observations |title=Field Observations: An Interview with Wendell Berry |first=Jordan |last=Fisher-Smith |work=The Sun Magazine |year=1994 |accessdate=December 21, 2017 }}</ref>
The effect of profound shifts in the agricultural practices of the United States, and the disappearance of traditional agrarian life,<ref>Cochrane, Willard Wesley. The Development of American Agriculture: A Historical Analysis. University of Minnesota Press, 1993. pp.122–149.</ref> are some of the major concerns of the Port William fiction, though the theme is often only a background or subtext to the stories themselves. The Port William fiction attempts to portray, on a local scale, what "a human economy … conducted with reverence"<ref>Berry, Wendell. "Imagination in Place." ''The Way of Ignorance.'' Washington, D. C.: Shoemaker & Hoard, 2005. p.50.</ref> looked like in the past—and what civic, domestic, and personal virtues might be evoked by such an economy were it pursued today. Social as well as seasonal changes mark the passage of time. The Port William stories allow Berry to explore the human dimensions of the decline of the family farm and farm community, under the influence of expanding post-[[World War II]] agribusiness. But these works rarely fall into simple didacticism, and are never merely tales of decline. Each is grounded in a realistic depiction of character and community. In ''A Place on Earth'' (1967), for example, farmer Mat Feltner comes to terms with the loss of his only son, Virgil. In the course of the novel, we see how not only Mat but the entire community wrestles with the acute costs of World War II.
Berry's fiction also allows him to explore the literal and metaphorical implications of [[marriage]] as that which binds individuals, families, and communities to each other and to Nature itself—yet not all of Port William is happily or conventionally married. "Old Jack" Beechum struggles with significant incompatibilities with his wife, and with a brief yet fulfilling extramarital affair. The barber Jayber Crow lives with a forlorn, secret, and unrequited love for a woman, believing himself "mentally" married to her even though she knows nothing about it. Burley Coulter never formalizes his bond with Kate Helen Branch, the mother of his son. Yet, each of these men find themselves firmly bound up in the community, the "membership," of Port William.
Of his fictional project, Berry has written: "I have made the imagined town of Port William, its neighborhood and membership, in an attempt to honor the actual place where I have lived. By means of the imagined place, over the last fifty years, I have learned to see my native landscape and neighborhood as a place unique in the world, a work of God, possessed of an inherent sanctity that mocks any human valuation that can be put upon it."<ref>"Imagination in Place" in ''Imagination in Place''. Berkeley: Counterpoint, 2010. p.15.</ref> Elsewhere, Berry has said, "The only thing I try to accomplish in fiction is to show how people act when they love each other."<ref>{{cite web |title=The Memory of Old Jack by Wendell Berry: A Review |work=Above the Fray |date=December 2, 2014 |url=http://www.deanabbott.com/the-memory-of-old-jack-by-wendell-berry-a-review/ |first=Dean |last=Abbott |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> The novels and stories can be read in any order.
In January, 2018, the [[Library of America]] published a volume of Berry's fiction—the first of a projected four volumes. ''Wendell Berry: Port William Novels & Stories (The Civil War to World War II)'' contains four novels and twenty-three short stories in chronological order according to the stories' events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://loa.org/books/567-port-william-novels-stories-the-civil-war-to-world-war-ii|title=Wendell Berry: Port William Novels & Stories (The Civil War to World War II)|last=|first=|date=|website=Library of America|access-date=February 25, 2018}}</ref> Along with [[W. S. Merwin]], Berry is one of two currently living writers in the Library of America catalog.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://loa.org/writers|title=Writers|last=|first=|date=|website=Library of America|access-date=February 25, 2018}}</ref>
===''Nathan Coulter'' (1960)=== In Berry's first novel, young Nathan "comes of age" through dealing with the death of his mother, the depression of his father Jared, the rugged companionship of his brother Tom, and the mischief of his uncle Burley. ''Kirkus Review'' concludes, "A sensitive adolescent theme is handled rather poetically, but so uniform in tone that no drama is generated and no sense of time passing is felt."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/wendell-berry-6/nathan-coulter/ |title="Nathan Coulter" by Wendell Berry |work=Kirkus Reviews |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> John Ditsky finds William Faulkner's influence in ''Nathan Coulter'', but notes, "Not only does the work avoid the pitfalls encountered by Faulkner's initial attempts to escape his postage stamp of native soil, but Nathan Coulter also seems a wise attempt to get that autobiographical first novel out of one's system, and to do so [with] honesty."<ref>John Ditsky, "Farming Kentucky: The Fiction of Wendell Berry," Hollins Critic 31, no. 1 (1994), https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-130929492/farming-kentucky-the-fiction-of-wendell-berry.</ref>
===''A Place on Earth'' (1967/1983)=== Set in the critical year of 1945, this novel focuses on farmer Mat Feltner's struggle over the news that his son Virgil has been listed as missing in action while also telling multiple tales of the lives of other Port William residents, such as Burley Coulter, Jack Beechum, Ernest Finley, Ida and Gideon Crop. Reprinting by North Point Press in 1983 allowed Berry to radically revise the novel,<ref>"Author's Note", ''A Place on Earth''. Berkeley: Counterpoint, 1999. p.xi.</ref> removing almost a third of its original length. Jeffrey Bilbro believes that these substantial changes marked growth in Berry's approach. "In Berry's revised edition, his technique caught up with his subject. He allows us, as readers, to participate in the ignorance of his characters, and in doing so, we may be able to understand more fully the painful difficulty of choosing fidelity to the natural order while living in the midst of mystery." <ref>"A Form for Living in the Midst of Loss: Faithful Marriage in the Revisions of Wendell Berry's ''A Place on Earth''" by Jeffrey Bilbro in ''The Southern Literary Journal'', Spring 2010 https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-228995624/a-form-for-living-in-the-midst-of-loss-faithful-marriage</ref>
===''The Memory of Old Jack'' (1974)=== This third novel of Port William begins with Jack Beechum as a very old man in 1952 and continues back into his youth and maturity to uncover his life and work as a dedicated farmer, conflicted husband, and living link to past generations. The story ranges from the Civil War to just past World War II. Josh Hurst comments on Berry's ability to avoid certain narrative pitfalls, "Jack's story could be presented us either as heroic ballad or as cautionary [tale]—and there is much in his life to support both admiration and gentle tisk-tisking—but the gift of this book is how it allows a man's memories to wash over us as though unshaped by narrative or conscious editorializing." <ref>"A Fiction of Remembering: Wendell Berry and The Memory of Old Jack" http://cahootsmag.com/2015/01/a-fiction-of-remembering-wendell-berry-and-the-memory-of-old-jack/</ref>
===''Remembering'' (1988)=== In Berry's fourth novel, an adult Andy Catlett wanders through San Francisco remembering, but feeling alienated from, his native Port William. He struggles to come to terms with himself, his marriage, his farm, and the distorted values of American society. Of Berry's vision here, Charles Solomon writes, "Wendell Berry contrasts modern American agribusiness--which he depicts as an artificial conglomeration of sterile flow charts, debts and mechanization--with the older ideal of farming as a nurturing way of life."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-09-16/books/bk-1082_1_wendell-berry|title=REMEMBERING By Wendell Berry (North Point Press: $7.95)|first=CHARLES|last=SOLOMON|date=September 16, 1990|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref> But along these lines, Bruce Bawer finds a problem with the novel, "Here, for the first time in a Port William novel, Berry seems more interested in communicating opinions than in portraying sympathetic characters in plausible situations; the opening episode, set at a conference on agricultural policy, paints the ideological conflict between Andy and his adversaries in broad, unsubtle strokes." <ref>"Membership & memory: A review of ''Fidelity'' by Wendell Berry" by Bruce Bawer http://www.newcriterion.com/articles.cfm/Membership---memory-4642</ref>
===''A World Lost'' (1996)=== Young Andy Catlett's uncle Andrew had been murdered back in 1944, and now an adult Andy is reconstructing the event and its aftermath. "Looking back with a mixture of a young boy's incomprehension and an older man's nostalgia, Andy evokes the past not as a narrative but as a series of disembodied fragments in the flow of time."<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/books/books-in-brief-fiction-072109.html |title=A World Lost |first=Tobin |last=Harshaw |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 3, 1996 |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> In this fifth novel of Port William, Berry considers the violence of men and its impact on the family and community that must come to terms with it. "Berry shows us the psychic costs of misplaced family pride and social rigidity, and yet he also celebrates the benevolent blessing of familial love. This is simple, soul-satisfying storytelling, augmented by understated humor and quiet insight."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-887178-22-8 |title=Fiction Book Review: "A World Lost" by Wendell Berry |work=PublishersWeekly.com |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
===''Jayber Crow'' (2000)=== Port William's barber recounts his life's journey in Berry's sixth novel. Jayber's early life as an orphan near Port William is followed by studies towards a possible vocation to Church ministry. A questioning mind, however, sends him in other directions until he finds himself back in Port William with an ever-growing commitment to that place and its people. As ''Publisher's Weekly'' notes, "Crow's life, which begins as WWI is about to erupt, is emblematic of a century of upheaval, and Berry's anecdotal and episodic tale sounds a challenge to contemporary notions of progress. It is to Berry's credit that a novel so freighted with ideas and ideology manages to project such warmth and luminosity."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-58243-029-4 |title=Fiction Book Review: "Jayber Crow" by Wendell Berry |work=PublishersWeekly.com |accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
===''Hannah Coulter'' (2004)=== Berry's seventh novel presents a concise vision of Port William's "membership." The story encompasses Hannah's life, including the [[Great Depression]], [[World War II]], the postwar industrialization of agriculture, the flight of youth to urban employment, and the consequent remoteness of grandchildren. The tale is told in the voice of an old woman twice widowed, who has experienced much loss yet has never been defeated. Somehow, lying at the center of her strength is the "membership"—the fact that people care for each other and, even in absence, hold each other in a kind of presence. All in all, ''Hannah Coulter'' embodies many of the themes of Berry's Port William saga.
===''Andy Catlett: Early Travels'' (2006)=== Andy Catlett, age nine, makes his first solo journey to visit with both sets of grandparents in Port William. ''The New York Times'' reviewer notes, "What the grown-up Andy recalls of that experience is transformed into 'a sort of homage' to a now-vanished world. Title characters from Berry's earlier Port William volumes — Jayber Crow, Old Jack, Hannah Coulter — appear here in affectionate cameos as the adult Andy, echoing Wordsworth, observes that 'in my memory, all who were there ... seem now to be gathered into a love that is at once a boy's and an aging man's.'"<ref>{{cite news |first=Roy |last=Hoffman |title=Boy on the Bus |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 28, 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/28/books/review/Hoffman.t.html?_r=0 |subscription=yes}}</ref>

[[File:Mimosa.13MmL-.33.jpg|thumb|Child and youth activists protesting at a demonstration in [[Hong Kong]]]] {{Youth rights sidebar}} '''Youth activism''' is youth engagement in [[community organizing]] for [[social change]]. Youth participation in social change focuses more on issue-oriented activism than traditional partisan or electoral politics.{{cite journal|last=Bonvillani|first=Andrea|title=Juventud y política en la Argentina (1968-2008): Hacia la construcción de un estado del arte|journal=Revista Argentina de Sociología|year=2008|volume=6|issue=11|pages=44–73|url=http://biblioteca.clacso.edu.ar/ar/libros/grupos/jovenes.pdf|display-authors=etal}} Youth have taken lead roles in public protests and advocacy around anti-war activism,{{cite book|last=Gordon|first=H.R.|title=We Fight to Win: Inequality and the Politics of Youth Activism|year=2010|publisher=Rutgers U Press|location=Rutgers, NJ|isbn=9780813548272|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/books/9780813548272/}} anti-crime and government corruption,{{cite journal|last=Harlow|first=S.|title=Social media and social movements: Facebook and an online Guatemalan justice movement that moved offline|journal=New media and society|year=2011|volume=14|issue=2|pages=225–243|doi=10.1177/1461444811410408|url=http://nms.sagepub.com/content/early/2011/08/04/1461444811410408}} [[The Education of Shelby Knox|pro-sexual education]], anti-government censorship, expanded educational access, and public transportation access. Technology and the use of digital media has changed the way youth participate in activism globally, and youth are more active in media than older generations.{{cite journal|last=Valenzuela|first=Sebastián|title=Unpacking the Use of Social Media for Protest Behavior The Roles of Information, Opinion Expression, and Activism|journal=American Behavioral Scientist|year=2013|volume=57|issue=7|pages=920–942|doi=10.1177/0002764213479375|url=http://abs.sagepub.com/content/57/7/920.abstract}} ==Overview== {{POV section|date=November 2013}} Young people are often underrepresented in politics because adults dominate the discourse. However, many youth are concerned and informed citizens who can advocate for change within their communities.{{cite book|last=Sherrod|first=Lonnie R|title=Youth activism: an international encyclopedia, Volume 2|year=2006|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group}}{{Page needed|date=September 2013}} Youth is an elastic category, the age at which it begins and ends varies within cultural contexts, but it is often a very distinct stage in a person’s life to which particular issues or policies are highly relevant. These may include politics, health, and social issues.{{cite book|last=Noguera|first=Pedro|title=Beyond Resistance! Youth Activism and Community Change: New Democratic Possibilities for Practice and Policy for America's Youth|year=2006|publisher=CRC Press}}{{Page needed|date=September 2013}} Sociopolitical development is a "psychological process that covers the range of cognitions, skills, attitudes, worldviews, and emotions that support social and political action" (Watts, Griffith, & Abdul-Adil, 1999).Watts, R. J., Griffith, D. M., & Abdul-Adil, J. (1999). Sociopolitical Development as an Antidote for Oppression—Theory and Action. American Journal of Community Psychology, 27(2), 255-271. The process of SPD was further defined by Watts & Flannagan "to impact young people’s social analysis, worldview and sense of agency and to provide them opportunity structures and support towards their societal involvement behavior (2007)."Watts, R. J., & Flanagan, C. (2007). Pushing the envelope on youth civic engagement: A developmental and liberation psychology perspective. Journal of Community Psychology, 35(6), 779-792. Social activism is the predominant form of youth activism today, as millions of young people around the world participate in social activism that is organized, informed, led, and assessed by adults. Many efforts, including [[education reform]], [[children's rights]], and [[Reform movement|government reform]] call on youth to participate this way, often called [[youth voice]]. [[Youth council]]s are an example of this.Chawla, L. (2002) Growing Up in an Urbanizing World. Paris/London: Earthscan/UNESCO Publishing.{{Page needed|date=September 2013}} Youth-driven activism requires young people to be the primary movers within an adult-led movement. Such is the case with the Sierra Club, where youth compel their peers to join and become active in the environmental movement. This is also true of many organizations that were founded by youth who became adults, such as [[Student Environmental Action Coalition|SEAC]] and [[National Youth Rights Association]].{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} Political activism by youth can go unnoticed because youth activism often occurs on school grounds and away from the adult society, but youth often face resistance when forming youth activist groups in schools.Gordon, H. (2010). We fight to win. New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press. As the central beneficiaries of [[Public school (government funded)|public schools]], youth are also advocating for [[student-led school change]] and [[education reform]] through [[student activism]] and meaningful [[Student engagement|student involvement]].Checkoway, B. & Gutierrez, L. (2006) "An introduction," in Checkoway & Gutierrez (eds) Youth Participation and Community Change. New York: Hawthorne Press. p 3. There are structural inequalities that keep youth from engaging in political talk and action on school grounds or the public domain. School clubs require an adult adviser to make the club official, further adding to school hierarchies of adult power. While some youth participate in [[student government]], others prefer [[Students' union|student unions]] because they provide a real voice to the students and present it to the administration while student governments do not have the power to effect real change in a school system. ==Technology== ===Social media=== [[Facebook]] has become a tool for youth activists to gather information, post [[broadcast]]s about events and activities, participate in activists' groups, and get in contact with other activists. [[Twitter]] is another tool. Although it is used to provide links to activism topics and activities, it is not regarded to be as useful because of the limitation of 140 characters per message.Zhang, W. (2013). Redefining youth activism through digital technology in Singapore. International Communication Gazette, 75(3), 253-270. doi:10.1177/1748048512472858 Twitter has also been used to spread awareness of social issues by using [[hashtags]]. Some of these movements included [[Kony 2012]] and [[Trayvon Martin]].Carr, D. (2012, March 25). Hashtag activism, and its limits. New York Times ===Video blogging=== [[Video blogging]] may be used by youth activists as a tool to reach out to their peers and audience, gather support, establish a discourse, and mobilize others. Young activists use videos to articulate ideas and needs, organize resources and supporters, and work toward achieving the goals and causes of their supporters.Lim, J. (2013). Video blogging and youth activism in Malaysia. International Communication Gazette, 75(3), 300-321. Video blogs are usually found through linking in social media sites such as Facebook, Twitter, and [[Instagram]], as well as on [[YouTube]]. ===Indymedia=== [[Independent Media Center]], also known as Indymedia, is a recent development that has helped involve youth into social movement activism. It has also led to the recognition of youth as political actors in the public domain. == Global youth activism == Youth activism in the [[Global South]] increased in the first years of the 2010s.Jeffrey, C. 2013. Geographies of children and youth III: Alchemists of the revolution? Progress in Human Geography 37(1): 145-152. People under the age of 18 comprise 46% of the global population, and these youth played a crucial role around the world during the first two decades of the twenty-first century.{{cite book|last=Wolf|first=Linda|title=Global Uprising: Confronting the Tyrannies of the 21st Century : Stories from a New Generation of Activists|year=2001|publisher=New Society Publ.}}{{Page needed|date=September 2013}} ===Africa=== ==== South Africa ==== A classic example of youth engagement in political activism is the [[Soweto riots]]. When teachers started instructing in [[Afrikaans]], the language of their oppressors, children took the streets for a peaceful demonstration. The police reaction was brutal and on June 16, 1976, at least 25 people were killed. The violence continued and spread all across the country. By the end of the year, 575 people had died and 2,389 had been wounded. A contemporary challenge for [[South Africa]]n youth is the AIDS pandemic. Around 60% of adults who contract HIV become infected before they turn 25, meaning youth are particularly endangered. To advocate and protest about HIV/AIDS, South African youth known as "urban warriors" have created social movements that use youth culture, media, and peer-to-peer campaigns to advocate about HIV/AIDS.{{cite book|last=Sherrod|first=Lonnie R|title=Youth activism: an international encyclopedia|year=2006|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group}}{{Page needed|date=September 2013}} ===Asia=== In Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Federation of Students leads the social umbrella movement against the decision of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPCSC) of 31 August. ==== India ==== In India, youth born in the 1980s and 1990s comprise part of a middle class increasingly vocal against impunity for rapists and against government corruption.Chandrashekar, V. 2013. "Could gang-rape protests mark beginning of an age of activism for India?" ''The Christian Science Monitor''. January 3, 2013. Web. Date Accessed: 2013/03/07. The [[Assam Movement]] (or Assam Agitation) (1979-1985) was a popular movement against illegal immigrants in Assam. The movement, led by [[All Assam Students Union]](AASU) and the 'All Assam Gana Sangram Parishad' (AAGSP), developed a program of protests and demonstration to compel the [[Indian government]] to identify and expel illegal, (mostly [[Bangladeshis]]), immigrants and protect and provide constitutional, legislative and administrative safeguards to the indigenous [[Assamese people]].{{Cite journal|title=Historical Background of Youth Activism in Assam|url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/194323/8/08_chapter%203.pdf|journal=shodhganga|pages=60}}{{Cite journal|title=Role of the Student of Assam Since Independence|url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/67807/14/14_chapter%205.pdf|journal=shodhganga}}{{Cite journal|title=Origin, Growth & Activities of AASU|url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/67057/7/07_chapter%202.pdf|journal=shodhganga}}{{Cite journal|title=Impact of AASU on Assam Politics|url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/67057/11/11_chapter%206.pdf|journal=shodhganga}}{{Cite journal|title=Youth Activism and Democratic Politics in India’s Northeast-2014 Election in Perspective|url=https://www.thehinducentre.com/migration_catalog/article22982380.ece/BINARY/Policy%20Report%20No.14|journal=The Hindu Centre for Politics & Public Policy}} On 16 January 2017 a large group of students (more than 20 lakhs) protested in [[Tamil Nadu]] and [[Puducherry]] for the ban on [[Jallikattu]]. The ban was made by Supreme court of India in 2014 when PETA filed a petition against Jallikattu as a cruelty to animals. [[Young India Foundation]] has been working on a campaign to decrease the age of candidacy in India of MPs/MLAs from 25 to better reflect the large young demographic of India called India's Age of Candidacyhttps://ageofcandidacy.in ==== Indonesia ==== Youth activism in [[Indonesia]] takes many different forms and include a number of mass protests to overthrow governments and remove colonial powers in the past. Popular motivations of youth activism in Indonesia are indigenous rights and national unity, pro-communism, anticommunism, pro-democracy and militant Islam. A common form of activism is massa, a cavalcade of motorcycles, trucks, music, and many young people on foot. These cavalcades are mostly males and end with a rally to address a certain political issue. In general, youth have been looking for political change during the last four decades. ==== Malaysia ==== Video blogging has become increasing popular in Malaysia. Youth activists upload their videos and independent films to the popular site [[EngageMedia]]. This is used by Malaysians to encourage young people to become citizen journalists. Youth view EngageMedia as a safe space for their video blogs, but there is still fear of retribution. ====Nepal==== In Nepal, [[Youth For Blood]] is working to solve the nation's problem of blood scarcity. They support patients to find fresh blood, award people for donating blood, and advocate to pressure the authorities for quality blood transfusion services and policies. ==== Singapore ==== Singapore is one of the most developed information and communication technology (ICT) countries in the world. In 2010 the computer ownership rate was 84 percent, with internet access at 78 percent. In 2009, mobile phone penetration reached 137 percent, meaning many people of Singapore have access to more than one phone. Youth use ICT for social and political purposes. In the 2011 general election, people between the ages of 21 and 34 were more active in online politics. Youth who wrote about elections on blogs, Facebook or Twitter were at 28 percent, while the general public were only 10 percent. ===Middle East=== ==== Egypt ==== Youth proved to be central to the Egyptian Revolution and the [[April 6 Movement]]. ==== Iran ==== Young adults in Iran defy the official regime's cultural and political policies through engaging in prohibited activities in places like taxi rides, coffee shops, and basements. Such actions re-imagine Iranian reality in ways that contest regime policies.Khosravi, S. 2008. Young and Defiant in Tehran. University of Pennsylvania Press, pp. 169-170, 174 ==== Saudi Arabia ==== Youth citizens of [[Saudi Arabia]] seek quiet forms of resistance because outright activism is prohibited. Students blog to share viewpoints and feelings despite potential personal risk.{{cite book|last=Ahmari|first=Sohrab|authorlink=Sohrab Ahmari|title=Arab Spring Dreams: The Next Generation Speaks Out for Freedom and Justice from North Africa to Iran|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan, 2012}}{{Page needed|date=September 2013}} ===Europe=== ==== Serbia ==== Throughout the 1900s, youth took to the streets to protest against Serbian leader [[Slobodan Milošević]]. Youth activists were credited with contributing to his resignation. During the years of protests youth faced unemployment, a failing education system, and economic instability. They created the [[Exit festival|Exit]] music festival, which lasted one hundred days and led up to the September 2000 elections. The first year this festival was called [[EXIT festival#Exit 00|EXIT 00]] and has been defined as "creative" and "politically savvy" activism. The festival contained a civic education component and continues today. ===North America=== ==== United States ==== Youth activism as a social phenomenon in the United States truly became defined in the mid- to late-nineteenth century when young people began forming labor strikes in response to their working conditions, wages, and hours. [[Mary Harris Jones|Mary Harris "Mother" Jones]] organized the first youth activism in the U.S., marching 100,000 child miners from the coal mines of [[Pennsylvania]] to the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C. in 1908. Youth newspaper carriers soon followed. These actions isolated youths' interests in the [[popular media]] of the times, and separated young people from their contemporary adult labor counterparts.{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} This separation continued through the 1930s, when the [[American Youth Congress]] presented a "Bill of Youth Rights" to the US Congress. Their actions were indicative of a growing student movement present throughout the US from the 1920s through the early 1940s. The 1950s saw the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]] bring young people into larger movements for [[civil rights]]. All the way back in 1959, Rev. Dr. [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] engaged youth activists in protesting against [[Bull Connor]]'s racist law enforcement practices in [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. The youth activism of [[Tom Hayden]], [[Keith Hefner (activist)|Keith Hefner]] and other 1960s youth laid a powerful precedent for modern youth activism. [[John Caldwell Holt|John Holt]], [[Myles Horton]] and [[Paulo Freire]] were important in this period. Youthful life and expression defined this era. == Youth activism in the 21st century == {{Cleanup section|reason=Needs to be summarized, possibly merged into other sections. Also predominantly focuses on activism in or from the USA|date=June 2018}} Youth activism continues to take place in the 21st century at local, regional, national, and international levels. Youth activists today use technology and social media to share their message. This makes it easier for a local or regional protest to gain national and international recognition. Additionally, a local or regional protest may, in fact, be focused on inequity or oppression in another part of the world.{{Cite news|url=https://edtechtimes.com/2017/05/30/youth-social-media-and-smartphone-use-a-problem-or-tool-for-good/|title=Youth Social Media and Smartphone Use: A Problem or Tool for Good?|date=2017-05-30|work=EdTech Times|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.youthforchange.org/latest-posts/2016/8/12/youth-digital-media-and-activism|title=Youth, Activism and the Power of Digital Media|work=Youth For Change: a global platform for girls' rights youth activism|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.uml.edu/News/stories/2017/PrendergastStudents.aspx|title=Activist: Students Are Leaders of Social Change|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en}} === 2001 ===

Since 2001, various legislation in the United States, commonly known as [[DREAM Act|DREAM]], has been proposed to help undocumented migrant youth and young adults who arrived as children. In 2012, President Obama authorized the [[Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals]] (DACA) program, which has a similar purpose. [[United We Dream]]{{Cite news|url=https://unitedwedream.org/|title=United We Dream {{!}} The Largest Immigrant Youth-Led Network in the Country|date=2017-04-12|work=United We Dream|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en}} is an immigrant youth-led community established in 2015. In collaboration with other activist groups, they have coordinated four campaigns: #RIGHT2DREAM in 2012; #WECANTWAIT in 2014; and END OF 287G IN HOUSTON and PROTECT IN-STATE TUITION IN TEXAS in 2017.

=== 2007 === In 2007, [[Jazz Jennings]] {{Cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-teen-titans-2318113|title=Teen Titans {{!}} Five young inspiring leaders changing the world {{!}} Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=2017-02-10|work=dna|access-date=2018-04-26|language=en-US}} gained national attention in the United States at the age of 6 when she was interviewed by [[Barbara Walters]] on [[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]] about being a transgender girl. Also, in 2007, she and her family founded the T[[ranskids Purple Rainbow Foundation]], whose mission includes financial resources for homeless transyouth in need, education, and advocacy. {{Cite web|url=http://www.transkidspurplerainbow.org/|title=TransKids Purple Rainbow Foundation|website=TransKids Purple Rainbow Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-28}} In 2014, Time magazine included Jennings on their list of most influential teenagers in the world. === 2010 === In 2010, the [[Student/Farmworker Alliance]] worked with [[Coalition of Immokalee Workers (CIW)]] to improve work standards for migrant workers in Florida.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/top-14-student-activism-stories-year/|title=The Top 14 Student Activism Stories of The Year|last=Goyette|first=Braden|date=2011-01-15|work=The Nation|access-date=2018-04-26|last2=Rothberg|first2=Peter|language=en-US|issn=0027-8378}} Also, in 2010, the student activist group [[United Students Against Sweatshops]] successfully campaigned for Nike to improve standards for their workers in [[Honduras]]. Their slogan was an effective play on words of Nike's slogan: Just Pay it.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/pressured-students-nike-agrees-help-workers-honduras/|title=Pressured by Students, Nike Agrees to Help Workers in Honduras|last=Ross|first=Aaron|date=2010-07-26|work=The Nation|access-date=2018-04-26|language=en-US|issn=0027-8378}} === 2011 === Heather Jarvis is a youth activist who co-founded [[SlutWalk]] with Sonja Barnett. SlutWalk's core principle is that women should be able to wear whatever they choose without being harassed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.tentree.com/blogs/posts/ten-inspirational-young-activists|title=Ten Inspirational Young Activists|last=etheme.com|work=tentree|access-date=2018-04-26}} SlutWalks have occurred in numerous countries. === 2012 === While [[Malala Yousafzai]] has been an activist for female education, initially in Pakistan, since 2009, support for her cause reached international levels after she was shot by a Taliban gunman in 2012 because of her activism. Since then, Yousafzai has established a non-profit organization{{Cite web|url=https://www.malala.org/|title=Malala Fund|last=Fund|first=Malala|website=www.malala.org|access-date=2018-04-28}} and received the [[Nobel Peace Prize]]. She also was the catalyst for a United Nations campaign for children's education world-wide. {{Cite web|url=http://freedomcenter.org/voice/young-powerful-and-influential-how-malala-yousafzai-changing-world|title=Young, Powerful and Influential: How Malala Yousafzai is Changing the World {{!}} National Underground Railroad Freedom Center|website=freedomcenter.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-28}} While there has been controversy associated with the [[Kony 2012|KONY 2012]] documentary video, it nonetheless became a viral sensation, in part, due to activist college students and teenagers. {{Cite news|url=https://vtdigger.org/2012/03/11/champlain-college-activists-bring-invisible-childrens-kony-2012-campaign-to-campus/|title=Champlain College activists bring Invisible Children's "Kony 2012" campaign to campus|date=2012-03-11|work=VTDigger|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2012/04/central_new_york_college_high.html|title=Central New York college, high school students take part tonight in Kony 2012|work=syracuse.com|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://lsa.umich.edu/lsa/news-events/all-news/search-news/activism-then--activism-now.html|title=Activism Then, Activism Now {{!}} U-M LSA U-M College of LSA|website=lsa.umich.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-28}} === 2013 === While the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement is not entirely a youth activist group, its founders were three young women who established it in response to the acquittal of the man who killed [[Trayvon Martin]], an unarmed 17-year-old African American.{{Cite web|url=https://blacklivesmatter.com/about/what-we-believe/|title=What We Believe|last=|first=|date=|website=Black Lives Mater|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Black Youth Project 100 ([[BYP100]]) was also established in response to that, but it limits participation to those aged 18 to 35. These two groups have worked together, and with others, to protest police killings of black people.{{Cite news|url=https://www.colorlines.com/articles/watch-young-activists-disrupt-anita-alvarez-fundraiser-say-byeanita|title=WATCH: Young Activists Disrupt Anita Alvarez Fundraiser, Say #ByeAnita|last=Rankin|first=Kenrya|date=2016-02-24|work=Colorlines|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en}} Unlike BYP 100, Black Lives Matters has become an international movement with chapters outside of the United States{{Cite web|url=http://www.blackpast.org/perspectives/black-lives-matter-growth-new-social-justice-movement|title=Black Lives Matter: The Growth of a New Social Justice Movement {{!}} The Black Past: Remembered and Reclaimed|website=www.blackpast.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-28}} When the Ukrainian president presented a drastically reduced budget for fighting AIDS, [[Liza Yaroshenko]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-21942921|title=Ukraine's youngest HIV campaigner|last=Ash|first=Lucy|date=2013-04-09|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-04-26|language=en-GB}}, then aged 14, addressed the parliament, asking them to veto that budget. As of 2017, Yaroshenko was still continuing her awareness campaign online. === 2016 === While the causes of the [[Flint water crisis|Flint Water Crisis]] have been determined by independent investigators,{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/03/23/471585633/independent-investigators-state-officials-mostly-to-blame-for-flint-water-crisis|title=Independent Investigators: State Officials Mostly To Blame For Flint Water Crisis|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en}} the crisis is not yet resolved as work to replace the corroded water lines is slightly more than one third completed, with 7,750 of more than 22,000 lead-contaminated water services lines to replace.{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc12.com/content/news/New-team-tackling-replacement-of-lead-service-lines-in-Flint-introduced-at-community-forum-472278473.html|title=New team tackling replacement of lead service lines in Flint introduced at community forum|last=Hybels|first=Amy|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en}} In 2016, Flint resident [[Amariyanna "Mari" Copeny]], aged 8, wrote President Obama to bring to his attention the public health crisis caused the Flint Water crisis. President Obama accepted her invitation to come to Flint.{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-read-little-miss-flint-letter-20160504-snap-htmlstory.html|title=Read the letter from 'Little Miss Flint' that stirred Obama to visit Flint|last=staff|first=Los Angeles Times|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-04-28}} In April 2018, [[Rick Snyder|Governor Rick Snyder]] announced that water quality is "within the standards" and the lead level doesn't exceed federal limits. This has resulted in the termination of a free bottled water program.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2016/03/04/us/flint-water-crisis-fast-facts/index.html|title=Flint Water Crisis Fast Facts|last=Library|first=CNN|work=CNN|access-date=2018-04-28}} {{Cite news|url=http://ktla.com/2018/04/07/michigan-will-end-flints-free-bottled-water-program-despite-residents-continued-concerns/|title=Michigan Will End Flint’s Free Bottled Water Program Despite Residents’ Continued Concerns|date=2018-04-07|work=KTLA|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/11/us/flint-michigan-water-rally/index.html|title=Flint residents rally in Michigan's capital against end of bottled water program|last=CNN|first=Ray Sanchez,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-04-28}} Since then, Copeny, also known as Little Miss Flint, continues to work to improve the lives of youth in her community. Not only has she, in collaboration with [[Pack Your Back]], raised more than $27,000 to provide thousands of bottled water since the government program was stopped, {{Cite web|url=https://www.packyourback.org/|title=packyourback|website=packyourback|language=en|access-date=2018-04-28}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc12.com/content/news/Little-Miss-Flint-joining-union-laborers-to-pass-out-bottled-water-Saturday-481115951.html|title='Little Miss Flint' joining union laborers to pass out bottled water Saturday|last=Team|first=ABC12 News|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en}} she has also raised money to provide 800 seats for under-served children to see [[Black Panther (film)|Blank Panther]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/inspired-life/wp/2018/02/20/10-year-old-little-miss-flint-helped-hundreds-of-underprivileged-kids-see-black-panther-over-the-weekend/|title=10-year-old ‘Little Miss Flint’ helped hundreds of underprivileged kids see ‘Black Panther’ over the weekend|last=Klein|first=Allison|date=2018-02-20|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} and crowdfunded to send Flint youth to see [[A Wrinkle in Time (2018 film)|A Wrinkle in Time]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.shondaland.com/inspire/a19485789/getting-to-work-with-little-miss-flint/|title=Getting to Work With Little Miss Flint|date=2018-03-22|work=Shondaland|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US}} {{Cite web|url=https://www.gofundme.com/a-wrinkle-in-time-4-flint-kids|title=Click here to support A Wrinkle In Time 4 Flint Kids organized by LuLu Brezzell|website=gofundme.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-28}} Prior to these fundraising endeavors, she first worked with Pack Your Back to fill 1,000 backpacks for Flint students.{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Lifestyle/meet-10-year-donated-1000-backpacks-flint-students/story?id=49133870|title=Meet the 10-year-old who donated 1,000 backpacks to Flint students|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2017-08-11|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-04-28}} At age 7, [[Bana al-Abed]] started using Twitter with her mother's assistance to share her experiences living in [[Aleppo|Aleppo, Syria]]. Al-Abed has become a world-renowned youth activist, publishing a memoir in 2017 and receiving the Asian Awards' Rising Star of the Year award in 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://asianstylemagazine.com/2018/04/19/bana-al-abed-and-sridevi-to-be-honoured-at-the-8th-asian-awards/|title=Bana al-Abed and Sridevi to be honoured at The 8th Asian Awards {{!}} Asian Style Magazine|website=asianstylemagazine.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-04-28}} === 2018 === The [[Stoneman Douglas High School shooting]] has resulted in not only some Stoneman Douglas students becoming youth activists for [[gun control]] legislation, but has also spurred a nation-wide resurgence of youth activism, including school walkouts.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/14/us/school-walkout.html|title=National School Walkout: Thousands Protest Against Gun Violence Across the U.S.|last=Yee|first=Vivian|date=2018-03-14|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-28|last2=Blinder|first2=Alan|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} {{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/c183323b5e6546419ae08b8c469b065a|title=US students stage massive walkout to protest gun violence|work=AP News|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US}} A group of Stoneman Douglas students also founded the advocacy group [[Never Again MSD]]. Never Again MSD led [[March for Our Lives]].{{Cite news|url=https://marchforourlives.com/home/|title=March for Our Lives - March For Our Lives|work=March For Our Lives|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US}} "Never Again" is also one of the group's hashtags{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5166976/florida-school-shooting-young-protesters/|title=Students Calling for Gun Control Can't Vote Yet. But Age Hasn't Stopped Young Activists in the Past|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-04-25}}, with the slogan having its roots as a resistance rallying cry during the Holocaust and is used by the [[Jewish Defense League]]. ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * Deka, Kaustubh [http://125.22.40.134:8082/jspui/bitstream/123456789/907/1/09_kaustubh_deka_op_9.pdf "From Movements to Accords and Beyond : The critical role of student organizations in the formation and performance of identity in Assam] Nehru Memorial Museum and Library, 2013 {{Media manipulation}} {{Youth empowerment}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Youth Activism}} [[Category:Activism]] [[Category:Education issues]] [[Category:Youth|A]]
